Compression with Exact Error Distribution for Federated Learning


 


Mahmoud Hegazy                        Rémi Leluc                        Cheuk Ting Li                        Aymeric Dieuleveut

École Polytechnique IPParis, France                        École Polytechnique IPParis, France                        Chinese University of Hong Kong Hong Kong, China                        École Polytechnique IPParis, France

Abstract

Compression schemes have been extensively used in Federated Learning (FL) to reduce the communication cost of distributed learning. While most approaches rely on a bounded variance assumption of the noise produced by the compressor, this paper investigates the use of compression and aggregation schemes that produce a specific error distribution, e.g., Gaussian or Laplace, on the aggregated data. We present and analyze different aggregation schemes based on layered quantizers achieving exact error distribution. We provide different methods to leverage the proposed compression schemes to obtain compression-for-free in differential privacy applications. Our general compression methods can recover and improve standard FL schemes with Gaussian perturbations such as Langevin dynamics and randomized smoothing.

1 INTRODUCTION

Machine learning has become increasingly data-hungry, requiring vast amounts of data to train models effectively. Federated learning (FL) (McMahan et al., 2017; Karimireddy et al., 2020; Kairouz et al., 2021b) has emerged as a promising approach for collaborative machine learning in distributed settings. In FL, multiple parties with their local datasets participate in a joint model training process without exchanging their raw data. However, communication from these devices to a central server can be slow and expensive resulting in a bottleneck. Thus, compression schemes have been widely used to reduce the size of the updates before transmission. Standard compression schemes (Konečnỳ et al., 2016; Alistarh et al., 2017; Wen et al., 2017; Lin et al., 2018; Li et al., 2022) typically assume relatively bounded variance assumptions on the noise produced by the compressor. These schemes do not take into account the specific error distribution of the noise, which may depend on the input distribution. This can be hindering in settings where control of the noise shape can provide tighter analysis or can enable the fulfilment of additional constraints, e.g. differential privacy.

In a wider scope, different structures of the compression error have been extensively leveraged beyond FL such as in: lossy data compression for audio and music compression (Johnston, 1988; Sayood, 2017); medical imaging (Liu et al., 2017; Ammah and Owusu, 2019); error control in wireless communications (Costello et al., 1998); quantization in deep learning (Rastegari et al., 2016) with weight pruning (Han et al., 2015; Anwar et al., 2017), low-precision weights (Jacob et al., 2018; Jung et al., 2019) and data perturbation for privacy-preserving machine learning (Abadi et al., 2016). In this context, the main goal of this paper is to answer the following research questions: (i) Can we go beyond standard assumptions on the variance and ensure a particular (continuous) distribution of the compression error? (ii) What are the benefits, communication cost and applications of such schemes?

Related work. Recently, different compression techniques with a precise noise distribution have been applied to various machine learning tasks. Agustsson and Theis (2020) apply subtractively dithered quantization (Roberts, 1962; Ziv, 1985; Zamir and Feder, 1992) to ensure a uniformly distributed noise in neural compression. Relative entropy coding (Havasi et al., 2019; Flamich et al., 2020) aims at compressing the model weights and latent representations to a number of bits approximately given by their relative entropy from a reference distribution. Differential privacy can be achieved by ensuring a precise noise distribution, using lattice quantization (Amiri et al., 2021; Lang et al., 2023), minimal random coding (Shah et al., 2022), or randomized encoding (Chaudhuri et al., 2022). These methods can be regarded as examples of channel simulation (Bennett et al., 2002; Harsha et al., 2010; Li and El Gamal, 2018), which is a point-to-point compression scheme where the output follows a precise conditional distribution given the input. Refer to (Yang et al., 2023; Theis et al., 2022) for more applications of channel simulation on neural compression.

In this paper, we not only consider a point-to-point compression setting, but also a distributed mean estimation and aggregation setting (Suresh et al., 2017), which is one of the most fundamental building blocks of FL algorithms (Kairouz et al., 2021b). There are n𝑛n users holding the data x1,…,xnsubscript𝑥1…subscript𝑥𝑛x_{1},\ldots,x_{n} respectively (which can be the gradient as in FedSGD, or the model weights as in FedAvg (McMahan et al., 2017)), who communicate with the server to allow the server to output an estimate Y𝑌Y of the mean, with a precise noise distribution Y−n−1​∑ixi∼Qsimilar-to𝑌superscript𝑛1subscript𝑖subscript𝑥𝑖𝑄Y-n^{-1}\sum_{i}x_{i}\sim Q, which can then be used to perform model updates with a more precise behavior.

There are two approaches to this problem, namely individual mechanisms where point-to-point compression is performed between each user and the server, and the server simply averages the reconstructions of the data of each user (possibly with some postprocessing); and aggregate mechanisms where the encoding functions of all users are designed as a whole to ensure a precise noise distribution of the final estimate Y𝑌Y. For individual mechanisms, we study the communication costs of the direct and shifted layered quantizers based on (Wilson, 2000; Hegazy and Li, 2022). For aggregate mechanisms, we propose a novel method, called the aggregate Gaussian mechanism, to ensure that the overall noise distribution Q𝑄Q is exactly Gaussian, and analyze its communication cost.

In particular, for differential privacy (DP), the above schemes allow us to consider two trust settings. First, for a completely trusted server, if the clients wish to prevent the output of the server from leaking information on their data x1,…,xnsubscript𝑥1…subscript𝑥𝑛x_{1},\ldots,x_{n}, a DP restriction (Dwork et al., 2006) can be imposed on the output Y𝑌Y. This is achieved by requiring the noise distribution Q𝑄Q to be a privacy-preserving noise distribution. For example, a Gaussian noise can guarantee (ε,δ)𝜀𝛿(\varepsilon,\delta)-DP (Dwork et al., 2014) and Rényi DP (Mironov, 2017). Second, when the server is less-trusted, the clients wish for the server to not know their individual datapoints but trust it to faithfully carry out some postprocessing to make the output DP against external observers. In this case, it is vital to ensure that the compression mechanism is homomorphic, and the messages sent from the users to the server can be aggregated before decoding, so that it is compatible with secure aggregation (SecAgg) techniques such as (Bonawitz et al., 2017) and other homomorphic cryptosystems. The aggregate Gaussian mechanism we propose is homomorphic, making it suitable for both privacy concerns of trusted and less-trusted servers.

Contributions. (1) We propose different quantized aggregation schemes based on layered quantizers that produce a specific error distribution, e.g. Gaussian or Laplace. (2) We provide theoretical guarantees and practical implementation of the developed aggregate mechanisms. (3) We exhibit FL applications in which we directly benefit from an exact Gaussian noise distribution, namely compression for free with differential privacy and compression schemes for Langevin dynamics and randomized smoothing.

2 BACKGROUND, MOTIVATION

Quantized aggregation. Consider n𝑛n clients (n≥1𝑛1n\geq 1). In the standard FL setting, the training process relies on locally generated randomness at individual participant devices. In this paper, we allow the clients and the server to have shared randomness. Practically, shared randomness can be generated by sharing a small random seed among the clients and the server, allowing them to generate a sequence of shared random numbers. We will see later that the existence of shared randomness can greatly simplify the schemes.

Let Si∈𝒮subscript𝑆𝑖𝒮S_{i}\in\mathcal{S} be the shared randomness between client i𝑖i and the server, and T∈𝒯𝑇𝒯T\in\mathcal{T} be the global shared randomness between all clients and the server. When building an FL algorithm, one is allowed to choose the joint distribution P(Si)i,Tsubscript𝑃subscriptsubscript𝑆𝑖𝑖𝑇P_{(S_{i})_{i},T} where these variables are usually (but not necessarily) taken to be mutually independent. Client i∈[n]𝑖delimited-[]𝑛i\in[n] holds the data xi∈ℝdsubscript𝑥𝑖superscriptℝ𝑑x_{i}\in\mathbb{R}^{d} and for privacy and communication constraints, performs encoding to produce the description Mi=ℰ​(xi,Si,T)∈ℳsubscript𝑀𝑖ℰsubscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝑆𝑖𝑇ℳM_{i}=\mathscr{E}(x_{i},S_{i},T)\in\mathcal{M}, where ℰ:ℝd×𝒮×𝒯→ℳ:ℰ→superscriptℝ𝑑𝒮𝒯ℳ\mathscr{E}:\mathbb{R}^{d}\times\mathcal{S}\times\mathcal{T}\to\mathcal{M} is the encoding function, and ℳℳ\mathcal{M} is the set of descriptions (usually taken to be ℤdsuperscriptℤ𝑑\mathbb{Z}^{d}). Given the descriptions M1,…,Mnsubscript𝑀1…subscript𝑀𝑛M_{1},\ldots,M_{n}, the server produces the reconstruction Y=𝒟¯​(M1,…,Mn,S1,…,Sn,T)𝑌¯𝒟subscript𝑀1…subscript𝑀𝑛subscript𝑆1…subscript𝑆𝑛𝑇Y=\overline{\mathscr{D}}(M_{1},\ldots,M_{n},S_{1},\ldots,S_{n},T) which is an estimate of the average n−1​∑i=1nxisuperscript𝑛1superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript𝑥𝑖n^{-1}\sum_{i=1}^{n}x_{i}, where 𝒟¯:ℳn×𝒮n×𝒯→ℝd:¯𝒟→superscriptℳ𝑛superscript𝒮𝑛𝒯superscriptℝ𝑑\overline{\mathscr{D}}:\mathcal{M}^{n}\times\mathcal{S}^{n}\times\mathcal{T}\to\mathbb{R}^{d} is the overall decoding function. The goal is to control the distribution of the quantization error as described in the next definition.

Definition 1.

(Aggregate AINQ mechanism) A quantization scheme with n𝑛n clients holding data x1,…,xnsubscript𝑥1…subscript𝑥𝑛x_{1},\ldots,x_{n} and a server producing Y𝑌Y satisfies the Additive Independent Noise Quantization (AINQ) property if the quantization error follows a target distribution Q𝑄Q regardless of {xi}i=1nsuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖𝑖1𝑛\left\{x_{i}\right\}_{i=1}^{n}, i.e.,

Y−(1n​∑i=1nxi)∼Q.similar-to𝑌1𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript𝑥𝑖𝑄Y-\left(\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}x_{i}\right)\sim Q. (1)

A special case is when n=1𝑛1n=1, which we call point-to-point AINQ mechanism. In this case, an AINQ mechanism with shared randomness S∈𝒮𝑆𝒮S\in{\cal S} can be performed in the following steps: (1) sample S∼PSsimilar-to𝑆subscript𝑃𝑆S\sim P_{S}, then (2) encode M=ℰ​(x,S)𝑀ℰ𝑥𝑆M={\mathscr{E}}(x,S) and (3) decode Y=𝒟​(M,S)𝑌𝒟𝑀𝑆Y={\mathscr{D}}(M,S). We do not require the global shared randomness T𝑇T here since it plays the same role as S𝑆S. We require the quantization noise to follow a particular distribution Y−x∼Qsimilar-to𝑌𝑥𝑄Y-x\sim Q. The simplest point-to-point AINQ mechanism is subtractively dithered quantization, which produces a uniform noise distribution.

Example 1.

(Subtractive Dithering) For a given step size w>0𝑤0w>0 and input X𝑋X, subtractive dithering works by sampling S∼𝒰​(−1/2,1/2)similar-to𝑆𝒰1212S\sim\mathcal{U}(-1/2,1/2), encoding the message M=⌈X/w+S⌋M=\lceil X/w+S\rfloor, and decoding Y=(M−S)​w𝑌𝑀𝑆𝑤Y=\left(M-S\right)w. Then Y−X∼𝒰​(−w/2;w/2)similar-to𝑌𝑋𝒰𝑤2𝑤2Y-X\sim\mathcal{U}(-w/2;w/2) and is independent of X𝑋X.

An aggregate AINQ mechanism for n𝑛n users can be constructed via a point-to-point AINQ mechanism. For this approach to be applicable, the overall quantization noise must have a divisible distribution that can be expressed as a sum of n𝑛n i.i.d. random variables.

Definition 2.

(Individual AINQ mechanism) An individual AINQ mechanism is an aggregate AINQ mechanism built via a point-to-point AINQ mechanism where the overall quantization noise Y−∑ixi𝑌subscript𝑖subscript𝑥𝑖Y-\sum_{i}x_{i} is divisible, T𝑇T is empty, the shared randomness is S1,…,Snsubscript𝑆1…subscript𝑆𝑛S_{1},\ldots,S_{n} which are i.i.d. copies of S𝑆S, user i𝑖i produces Mi=ℰ​(xi,Si)subscript𝑀𝑖ℰsubscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝑆𝑖M_{i}={\mathscr{E}}(x_{i},S_{i}) and the server outputs Y=n−1​∑i𝒟​(Mi,Si)𝑌superscript𝑛1subscript𝑖𝒟subscript𝑀𝑖subscript𝑆𝑖Y=n^{-1}\sum_{i}{\mathscr{D}}(M_{i},S_{i}).

Application 1: FL and Differential Privacy. The inherent sensitivity of individual data raises significant concerns about privacy breaches in the distributed setting. To address these challenges, the integration of differential privacy into federated learning has emerged as a compelling approach (Abadi et al., 2016; Truex et al., 2019; Wei et al., 2020; Noble et al., 2022).

Definition 3.

(Differential-Privacy (DP)) Any algorithm 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} is (ε,δ)𝜀𝛿(\varepsilon,\delta)-differentially private, if for all adjacent datasets 𝒟1subscript𝒟1\mathcal{D}_{1} and 𝒟2subscript𝒟2\mathcal{D}_{2} and all subsets E⊂Im​(𝒜)𝐸Im𝒜E\subset\mathrm{Im}(\mathcal{A})

ℙ​(𝒜​(𝒟1)∈E)≤eε​ℙ​(𝒜​(𝒟2)∈E)+δ,ℙ𝒜subscript𝒟1𝐸superscript𝑒𝜀ℙ𝒜subscript𝒟2𝐸𝛿\mathbb{P}(\mathcal{A}(\mathcal{D}_{1})\in E)\leq e^{\varepsilon}\mathbb{P}(\mathcal{A}(\mathcal{D}_{2})\in E)+\delta, (2)

where ℙℙ\mathbb{P} is over the randomness used by algorithm 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A}.

The Gaussian mechanism injects controlled noise into computations, allowing for a balance between privacy protection and data utility. For a function f𝑓f that operates on a dataset 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D}, it is defined as

G​(𝒟)=f​(𝒟)+𝒩​(0,σ2​I)G𝒟𝑓𝒟𝒩0superscript𝜎2I\mathrm{G}(\mathcal{D})=f(\mathcal{D})+\mathcal{N}(0,\sigma^{2}\mathrm{I})\vspace{-0.1cm} (3)

and it is guaranteed to be (ε,δ)𝜀𝛿(\varepsilon,\delta)-DP if the noise satisfies σ2≥2​Δ22​ln⁡(1.25/δ)/ε2superscript𝜎22subscriptsuperscriptΔ221.25𝛿superscript𝜀2\sigma^{2}\geq 2\Delta^{2}_{2}\ln{(1.25/\delta})/\varepsilon^{2} (Dwork et al., 2014) where Δ2=sup𝒟1,𝒟2∥f​(𝒟1)−f​(𝒟2)∥2subscriptΔ2subscriptsupremumsubscript𝒟1subscript𝒟2subscriptdelimited-∥∥𝑓subscript𝒟1𝑓subscript𝒟22\Delta_{2}=\sup_{\mathcal{D}_{1},\mathcal{D}_{2}}\left\lVert f(\mathcal{D}_{1})-f(\mathcal{D}_{2})\right\rVert_{2} for 𝒟1subscript𝒟1\mathcal{D}_{1} and 𝒟2subscript𝒟2\mathcal{D}_{2} differing on one element. While common privacy-preserving approaches rely on adding a Gaussian or Laplace noise on top of compression schemes, one can leverage AINQ mechanisms to directly obtain privacy guarantees with a reduced communication cost. For example, setting the compression error to be a properly scaled Gaussian recovers the Gaussian mechanism of Eq.(3).

Application 2: FL and Langevin dynamics. When solving the Bayesian inference problem in the FL setting (Vono et al., 2022), compression operators 𝒞:ℝd→ℝd:𝒞→superscriptℝ𝑑superscriptℝ𝑑\mathscr{C}:\mathbb{R}^{d}\to\mathbb{R}^{d} are commonly unbiased and have a bounded variance. with Zk∼𝒩d​(0,Id)similar-tosubscript𝑍𝑘subscript𝒩𝑑0subscriptI𝑑Z_{k}\sim\mathcal{N}_{d}(0,\mathrm{I}_{d}) and γ>0𝛾0\gamma>0. Using compression with exact error distribution, one can precisely control the distribution of the error (𝒞​(X)−X)𝒞𝑋𝑋(\mathscr{C}(X)-X) and recover the QLSD scheme of Vono et al. (2022) with a reduced communication cost. This may be done via the quantizer 𝒞γsubscript𝒞𝛾\mathscr{C}_{\gamma} such that 𝒞γ​(X)−X∼𝒩d​(0,2​Id/γ)similar-tosubscript𝒞𝛾𝑋𝑋subscript𝒩𝑑02subscriptI𝑑𝛾\mathscr{C}_{\gamma}(X)-X\sim\mathcal{N}_{d}(0,2\mathrm{I}_{d}/\gamma) along with the update rule θk+1=θk−γ​𝒞γ​(H​(θk))subscript𝜃𝑘1subscript𝜃𝑘𝛾subscript𝒞𝛾𝐻subscript𝜃𝑘\theta_{k+1}=\theta_{k}-\gamma\mathscr{C}_{\gamma}(H(\theta_{k})). (See Appendix C.2 for more details)

Application 3: FL and Randomized Smoothing. Fast rates for non-smooth optimization problems of the form minθ∈ℝd⁡{f​(θ)=∑i=1nfi​(θ)}subscript𝜃superscriptℝ𝑑𝑓𝜃superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript𝑓𝑖𝜃\min_{\theta\in\mathbb{R}^{d}}\{f(\theta)=\sum_{i=1}^{n}f_{i}(\theta)\} can be attained using the smoothing approach of Duchi et al. (2012); Scaman et al. (2018). These accelerated algorithms such as Distributed Randomized Smoothing (DRS) rely on a smoothed version fσsubscript𝑓𝜎f_{\sigma} of f𝑓f defined by

where ξ∼𝒩​(0,Id)similar-to𝜉𝒩0subscriptI𝑑\xi\sim\mathcal{N}(0,\mathrm{I}_{d}) and σ>0𝜎0\sigma>0. Each client approximate the smoothed gradient with a subgradient gisubscript𝑔𝑖g_{i} evaluated at m𝑚m perturbed points gi​(θ+σ​ξj)subscript𝑔𝑖𝜃𝜎subscript𝜉𝑗g_{i}(\theta+\sigma\xi_{j}) for j∈[m]𝑗delimited-[]𝑚j\in[m]. Interestingly, the sampling steps may be replaced with compressors that produce exact error distribution. In the spirit of Philippenko and Dieuleveut (2021), one can first compress the model parameter θ𝜃\theta with a Gaussian error distribution as ℰ​(θ)=θ+σ​ξℰ𝜃𝜃𝜎𝜉{\mathscr{E}}(\theta)=\theta+\sigma\xi and then evaluate the subgradients at compressed point as gi​(ℰ​(θ))subscript𝑔𝑖ℰ𝜃g_{i}({\mathscr{E}}(\theta)) to recover the classical DRS algorithm.

3 INDIVIDUAL MECHANISMS

In order to obtain a target noise distribution exactly, we describe two point-to-point AINQ mechanisms based on Hegazy and Li (2022) and on the layered multishift coupling in Wilson (2000), which can be used to construct n𝑛n-client individual AINQ mechanisms using Def. 2. For geometric interpretations, we refer to them respectively as the direct layered quantizer and the shifted layered quantizer. They both rely on subtractive dithering with step size w𝑤w to generate an error which follows a uniform distribution 𝒰​(−w/2,w/2)𝒰𝑤2𝑤2\mathcal{U}(-w/2,w/2), as in Example 1, but with a random step size w𝑤w.

3.1 Individual Mechanisms via Direct and Shifted Layered Quantizers

Consider a random variable Z𝑍Z following a unimodal distribution fZsubscript𝑓𝑍f_{Z}. Instead of having a deterministic value of w𝑤w, it is randomly sampled from an appropriate distribution ensuring that the marginal error follows fZsubscript𝑓𝑍f_{Z}. Define the superlevel set ℒx​(fZ)≔{u∈ℝ:fZ​(u)≥x}≔subscriptℒ𝑥subscript𝑓𝑍conditional-set𝑢ℝsubscript𝑓𝑍𝑢𝑥\mathcal{L}_{x}(f_{Z})\coloneqq\{u\in\mathbb{R}:f_{Z}(u)\geq x\} for any x∈ℝ𝑥ℝx\in\mathbb{R} and let Z¯≔max⁡fZ≔¯𝑍subscript𝑓𝑍\bar{Z}\coloneqq\max f_{Z}. For any x∈(0,Z¯)𝑥0¯𝑍x\in\left(0,\bar{Z}\right), define bZ−​(x)=infℒx​(fZ)superscriptsubscript𝑏𝑍𝑥infimumsubscriptℒ𝑥subscript𝑓𝑍b_{Z}^{-}(x)=\inf\mathcal{L}_{x}(f_{Z}) and bZ+​(x)=supℒx​(fZ)superscriptsubscript𝑏𝑍𝑥supremumsubscriptℒ𝑥subscript𝑓𝑍b_{Z}^{+}(x)=\sup\mathcal{L}_{x}(f_{Z}). As illustrated in Figure 1, for a unimodal distribution, sampling under the graph can be thought of as sampling from a infinite mixture of uniform distributions over continuous intervals.

Direct Layered Quantizer. In order to sample from a real continuous random variable, it is sufficient to uniformly sample in the area under its graph and then project onto the x𝑥x-axis. The construction below has been mentioned in the special case of Gaussian noise in Agustsson and Theis (2020), and studied in the general unimodal case in Hegazy and Li (2022).

Definition 4.

(Direct layered quantizer) Given any Z𝑍Z with a unimodal p.d.f. fZsubscript𝑓𝑍f_{Z}, the direct layered quantizer, producing an error Z𝑍Z, is defined using the encoder ℰℰ{\mathscr{E}}, the decoder 𝒟𝒟{\mathscr{D}}, and PSsubscript𝑃𝑆P_{S} such that S=(U,DZ)𝑆𝑈subscript𝐷𝑍S=(U,D_{Z}) with U∼𝒰​(0,1)similar-to𝑈𝒰01U\sim\mathcal{U}(0,1) independent of DZ∼fDsimilar-tosubscript𝐷𝑍subscript𝑓𝐷D_{Z}\sim f_{D} where the p.d.f. fDsubscript𝑓𝐷f_{D} is defined through the superlevel sets of fZsubscript𝑓𝑍f_{Z}. For all x∈ℝ𝑥ℝx\in\mathbb{R}, fD​(x)=λ​(ℒx​(fZ))=(bZ+​(x)−bZ−​(x))​𝟏(0,Z¯)​(x)subscript𝑓𝐷𝑥𝜆subscriptℒ𝑥subscript𝑓𝑍superscriptsubscript𝑏𝑍𝑥superscriptsubscript𝑏𝑍𝑥subscript10¯𝑍𝑥f_{D}(x)=\lambda(\mathcal{L}_{x}(f_{Z}))=\left(b_{Z}^{+}(x)-b_{Z}^{-}(x)\right)\mathbf{1}_{(0,\bar{Z})}(x) and

M=ℰ(X,S)=⌈X/fD(DZ)+U⌋,\displaystyle M={\mathscr{E}}(X,S)=\lceil X/f_{D}(D_{Z})+U\rfloor,
𝒟(M,S)=(M−U)fD(DZ)+bZ+​(DZ)+bZ−​(DZ)2⋅\displaystyle{\mathscr{D}}(M,S)=\left(M-U\right)f_{D}(D_{Z})+\frac{b_{Z}^{+}(D_{Z})+b_{Z}^{-}(D_{Z})}{2}\cdot

Shifted Layered Quantizer. Another approach for leveraging subtractive dithering is based on multishift coupling, as described in Wilson (2000). It is based on the idea of using a sequence of shifted uniform distributions to generate a sequence of target distributions. The key idea is that the sampling from an area A𝐴A and then projecting onto the x𝑥x-axis is equivalent to the sampling from any horizontal reflection of A𝐴A and then projecting onto the x𝑥x-axis. Thus, one can can flip one side of a unimodal distribution and still take samples from the part under the flipped side (see Figure 1 with the shifted distributions).

Definition 5.

(Shifted layered quantizer) Given any Z𝑍Z with a unimodal p.d.f. fZsubscript𝑓𝑍f_{Z}, the layered randomized quantizer, producing an error Z𝑍Z, is defined using the encoder ℰℰ{\mathscr{E}}, the decoder 𝒟𝒟{\mathscr{D}} and randomness PSsubscript𝑃𝑆P_{S} such that S=(U,WZ)𝑆𝑈subscript𝑊𝑍S=(U,W_{Z}) with U∼𝒰​(0,1)similar-to𝑈𝒰01U\sim\mathcal{U}(0,1) independent of WZ∼fWsimilar-tosubscript𝑊𝑍subscript𝑓𝑊W_{Z}\sim f_{W} where the p.d.f. fWsubscript𝑓𝑊f_{W} is defined through the superlevel sets of fZsubscript𝑓𝑍f_{Z}. For all x∈ℝ𝑥ℝx\in\mathbb{R} ,

fW​(x)=(bZ+​(x)−bZ−​(Z¯−x))​𝟏(0,Z¯)​(x),subscript𝑓𝑊𝑥superscriptsubscript𝑏𝑍𝑥superscriptsubscript𝑏𝑍¯𝑍𝑥subscript10¯𝑍𝑥\displaystyle f_{W}(x)=\left(b_{Z}^{+}(x)-b_{Z}^{-}(\bar{Z}-x)\right)\mathbf{1}_{\left(0,\bar{Z}\right)}(x),
ℰ(X,S)=⌈X/fW(WZ)+U⌋,\displaystyle{\mathscr{E}}(X,S)=\lceil X/f_{W}(W_{Z})+U\rfloor,
𝒟​(M,S)=(M−U)​fW​(WZ)+bZ+​(WZ)+bZ−​(Z¯−WZ)2.𝒟𝑀𝑆𝑀𝑈subscript𝑓𝑊subscript𝑊𝑍superscriptsubscript𝑏𝑍subscript𝑊𝑍superscriptsubscript𝑏𝑍¯𝑍subscript𝑊𝑍2\displaystyle{\mathscr{D}}(M,S)=\left(M\!-\!U\right)f_{W}(W_{Z})+\frac{b_{Z}^{+}(W_{Z})+b_{Z}^{-}(\bar{Z}\!-\!W_{Z})}{2}.

By construction, the shifted layered quantizer satisfies the AINQ property (see details in Appendix B.1).

3.2 Communication Complexity

To transmit the integer M𝑀M, we should encode it into bits. There are two general approaches. First, if a fixed-length code is used where M𝑀M is always encoded to the same number of bits, then ⌈log⁡|Supp⁡M|⌉Supp𝑀\lceil\log|\operatorname{Supp}M|\rceil bits are required. Second, if a variable-length code is used, for example, if we encode M𝑀M using the Huffman code (Huffman, 1952) on the conditional distribution pM|Ssubscript𝑝conditional𝑀𝑆p_{M|S}, then we require an expected encoding length bounded between ℋ⁡(M|S)ℋconditional𝑀𝑆\operatorname{\mathcal{H}}(M|S) and ℋ⁡(M|S)+1ℋconditional𝑀𝑆1\operatorname{\mathcal{H}}(M|S)+1. We will see that the direct layered quantizer gives a better variable-length performance, whereas the shifted layered quantizer gives a better fixed-length performance.

For variable-length codes, it has been shown in (Hegazy and Li, 2022, Theorem 4) that every AINQ scheme with error distribution fZsubscript𝑓𝑍f_{Z} and uniform input X∼𝒰​(0,t)similar-to𝑋𝒰0𝑡X\sim\mathcal{U}(0,t) must satisfy

ℋ⁡(M|S)≥log⁡(t)+h​(DZ),ℋconditional𝑀𝑆𝑡ℎsubscript𝐷𝑍\operatorname{\mathcal{H}}(M|S)\geq\log(t)+h(D_{Z}), (4)

where DZsubscript𝐷𝑍D_{Z} is defined in Definition 4, and −h​(DZ)ℎsubscript𝐷𝑍-h(D_{Z}) is called the layered entropy. It has also been shown in Hegazy and Li (2022) that the direct layered quantizer is almost optimal, in the sense that as long as Z𝑍Z has a unimodal distribution and Supp⁡(X)⊆[0,t]Supp𝑋0𝑡\operatorname{Supp}(X)\subseteq\left[0,t\right], it achieves

ℋ⁡(M|S)≤log⁡(t)+8​log⁡(e)t​𝕍⁡[Z]+h​(DZ).ℋconditional𝑀𝑆𝑡8𝑒𝑡𝕍𝑍ℎsubscript𝐷𝑍\operatorname{\mathcal{H}}(M|S)\leq\log(t)+\frac{8\log{(e)}}{t}\sqrt{\operatorname{\mathbb{V}}\left[Z\right]}+h(D_{Z}). (5)

The gap between (4) and (5) tends to 00 as t→∞→𝑡t\to\infty.

While the shifted layered quantizer is not asymptotically optimal, the optimality gap (the gap between the ℋ⁡(M|S)ℋconditional𝑀𝑆\operatorname{\mathcal{H}}(M|S) attained and its optimal value) is still relatively small as shown below.

Proposition 1.

(Optimality Gap) For a target unimodal noise distribution fZsubscript𝑓𝑍f_{Z} that is symmetric, the shifted layered quantizer achieves

ℋ⁡(M|S)≤log⁡(t)+8​log⁡(e)t​𝕍⁡[Z]+h​(WZ),ℋconditional𝑀𝑆𝑡8𝑒𝑡𝕍𝑍ℎsubscript𝑊𝑍\operatorname{\mathcal{H}}(M|S)\leq\log(t)+\frac{8\log(e)}{t}\sqrt{\operatorname{\mathbb{V}}\left[Z\right]}+h(W_{Z}),

and the optimality gap of using the shifted layered quantizer is upper bounded by (8​log⁡(e)/t)​𝕍⁡[Z]+28𝑒𝑡𝕍𝑍2(8\log(e)/t)\sqrt{\operatorname{\mathbb{V}}\left[Z\right]}+2.

Figure 2 below shows the conditional entropy ℋ⁡(M|S)ℋconditional𝑀𝑆\operatorname{\mathcal{H}}(M|S) needed to simulate a Gaussian noise and a Laplace noise with standard deviation σ∈{1;3}𝜎13\sigma\in\{1;3\} according to the support size t𝑡t where X∼𝒰​(0,t)similar-to𝑋𝒰0𝑡X\sim\mathcal{U}(0,t). The gap is smaller than 111 bit for all the values computed.

The advantage of the shifted layered quantizer is its fixed-length performance. A fixed-length code has the advantage that we do not have to build a Huffman code on the conditional distribution pM|Ssubscript𝑝conditional𝑀𝑆p_{M|S} for each S𝑆S, which may be infeasible. Since the shifted layered quantizer has a quantization step size bounded away from 00 as shown in Figure 1, it provides a fixed upper bound on the number of quantization bits.

Proposition 2.

(Minimal step size for shifted layered) For a required fZsubscript𝑓𝑍f_{Z}, denote by ηZsubscript𝜂𝑍\eta_{Z} the minimal step size of the shifted layer quantizer, i.e. ηZ≔min⁡fW≔subscript𝜂𝑍subscript𝑓𝑊\eta_{Z}\coloneqq\min f_{W}. Assume that the input X𝑋X lies in a fixed interval of length t𝑡t.
•  If Z∼Laplace​(0,σ/2)similar-to𝑍Laplace0𝜎2Z\sim\text{Laplace}(0,\sigma/\sqrt{2}) then ηZ=σ​2​ln⁡2subscript𝜂𝑍𝜎22\eta_{Z}=\sigma\sqrt{2}\ln{2} and |Supp⁡M|≤2+t/(σ​2​ln⁡2)Supp𝑀2𝑡𝜎22\left\lvert\operatorname{Supp}M\right\rvert\leq 2+t/(\sigma\sqrt{2}\ln{2}).

4 AGGREGATE MECHANISMS

4.1 Homomorphic Mechanisms

For an individual AINQ mechanism, the descriptions M1,…,Mnsubscript𝑀1…subscript𝑀𝑛M_{1},\ldots,M_{n} sent from the users must all be available to the server. The descriptions cannot be first aggregated into a single number before decoding. We study aggregate AINQ mechanisms where such “intermediate aggregation” of descriptions is possible.

Definition 6.

(Homomorphic) An aggregate AINQ mechanism is homomorphic if there exists functions 𝒟:ℳ×𝒮×𝒯→ℝd:𝒟→ℳ𝒮𝒯superscriptℝ𝑑\mathscr{D}:\mathcal{M}\times\mathcal{S}\times\mathcal{T}\to\mathbb{R}^{d} (called the homomorphic decoding function) such that the overall decoding function is

𝒟¯​(m1,s1,…,mn,sn,t)=1n​𝒟​(∑i=1nmi,∑i=1nsi,t)¯𝒟subscript𝑚1subscript𝑠1…subscript𝑚𝑛subscript𝑠𝑛𝑡1𝑛𝒟superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript𝑚𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript𝑠𝑖𝑡\overline{\mathscr{D}}(m_{1},s_{1},\ldots,m_{n},s_{n},t)=\frac{1}{n}\mathscr{D}\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n}m_{i},\,\sum_{i=1}^{n}s_{i},\,t\right) (6)

and for all t𝑡t, 𝒟​(⋅,⋅,t):ℳ×𝒮→ℝd:𝒟⋅⋅𝑡→ℳ𝒮superscriptℝ𝑑\mathscr{D}(\cdot,\cdot,t):\mathcal{M}\times\mathcal{S}\to\mathbb{R}^{d} is a homomorphism, i.e., 𝒟​(m,s,t)+𝒟​(m′,s′,t)=𝒟​(m+m′,s+s′,t)𝒟𝑚𝑠𝑡𝒟superscript𝑚′superscript𝑠′𝑡𝒟𝑚superscript𝑚′𝑠superscript𝑠′𝑡\mathscr{D}(m,s,t)+\mathscr{D}(m^{\prime},s^{\prime},t)=\mathscr{D}(m+m^{\prime},s+s^{\prime},t) for all m,m′,s,s′𝑚superscript𝑚′𝑠superscript𝑠′m,m^{\prime},s,s^{\prime}.

Here we require ℳℳ\mathcal{M} and 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S} to be abelian groups (e.g., ℳ=ℤdℳsuperscriptℤ𝑑\mathcal{M}=\mathbb{Z}^{d}, 𝒮=ℝd𝒮superscriptℝ𝑑\mathcal{S}=\mathbb{R}^{d}) so we can perform addition over ℳℳ\mathcal{M} and 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S}. For a homomorphic scheme, the server only requires the common randomness (Si)i,Tsubscriptsubscript𝑆𝑖𝑖𝑇(S_{i})_{i},T and the sum of the descriptions ∑i=1nMisuperscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript𝑀𝑖\sum_{i=1}^{n}M_{i}, not the individual descriptions M1,…,Mnsubscript𝑀1…subscript𝑀𝑛M_{1},\ldots,M_{n}.

In federated learning, homomorphic mechanisms have several advantages. First, the descriptions M1,…,Mnsubscript𝑀1…subscript𝑀𝑛M_{1},\ldots,M_{n} can be passed from the clients to the server through a network for sum computation (Ramamoorthy and Langberg, 2013; Rai and Dey, 2012; Qu et al., 2021; Rizk and Sayed, 2021), resulting in a reduction of communication cost. A simple method is to have each node in the network add all incoming signals and pass the sum to the next node. The internal nodes in the network do not need to access (Si)i,Tsubscriptsubscript𝑆𝑖𝑖𝑇(S_{i})_{i},T. Second, homomorphic mechanisms are compatible with SecAgg (Bonawitz et al., 2017) and other additive homomorphic cryptosystems. We can perform SecAgg on M1,…,Mnsubscript𝑀1…subscript𝑀𝑛M_{1},\ldots,M_{n} so that the server can only know ∑i=1nMisuperscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript𝑀𝑖\sum_{i=1}^{n}M_{i}, but not the individual Misubscript𝑀𝑖M_{i}’s so as to preserve privacy.

The layered quantizers of the previous section do not produce homomorphic mechanisms. The reason is that the quantization step sizes of the n𝑛n users are randomly drawn and different. Thus, the quantized data Misubscript𝑀𝑖M_{i}’s are at different scales and cannot be added together. A simple and naive way to obtain an homomorphic mechanism is to rely on subtractive dithering (Example 1) with a fixed step size w𝑤w for each user.

4.2 Irwin-Hall Mechanism

When applying subtractive dithering for each of the n𝑛n users, the resultant noise of the individual AINQ mechanism follows a scaled Irwin-Hall distribution. More precisely, consider S=(S1,…,Sn)𝑆subscript𝑆1…subscript𝑆𝑛S=(S_{1},\ldots,S_{n}) to be an i.i.d. sequence of 𝒰​(−1/2,1/2)𝒰1212\mathcal{U}(-1/2,1/2) random variables and T=0𝑇0T=0 to be degenerate. The encoding function is Mi=ℰ(xi,Si)=⌈xi/w+Si⌋M_{i}=\mathscr{E}(x_{i},S_{i})=\lceil x_{i}/w+S_{i}\rfloor where w:=2​σ​3​nassign𝑤2𝜎3𝑛w:=2\sigma\sqrt{3n}, and the decoding function is Y=w​(∑iMi−∑iSi)𝑌𝑤subscript𝑖subscript𝑀𝑖subscript𝑖subscript𝑆𝑖Y=w(\sum_{i}M_{i}-\sum_{i}S_{i}). The noise is a scaled Irwin-Hall distribution IH​(n,0,σ2)IH𝑛0superscript𝜎2\mathrm{IH}(n,0,\sigma^{2}), where IH​(n,μ,σ2)IH𝑛𝜇superscript𝜎2\mathrm{IH}(n,\mu,\sigma^{2}) denotes the distribution of n−1​∑i=1nZi+μsuperscript𝑛1superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript𝑍𝑖𝜇n^{-1}\sum_{i=1}^{n}Z_{i}+\mu with Z1,…,Zn∼i​i​d𝒰​(−σ​3​n,σ​3​n)superscriptsimilar-to𝑖𝑖𝑑subscript𝑍1…subscript𝑍𝑛𝒰𝜎3𝑛𝜎3𝑛Z_{1},\ldots,Z_{n}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle iid}}{{\sim}}\mathcal{U}(-\sigma\sqrt{3n},\,\sigma\sqrt{3n}). Note that IH​(n,0,σ2)IH𝑛0superscript𝜎2\mathrm{IH}(n,0,\sigma^{2}) has mean 00 and variance σ2superscript𝜎2\sigma^{2}, and approximates the Gaussian distribution 𝒩​(0,σ2)𝒩0superscript𝜎2\mathcal{N}(0,\sigma^{2}) when n𝑛n is large. We call this the Irwin-Hall mechanism.

While this mechanism is simple and homomorphic (the decoding function only depends on ∑iMisubscript𝑖subscript𝑀𝑖\sum_{i}M_{i} and ∑iSisubscript𝑖subscript𝑆𝑖\sum_{i}S_{i}), an obvious downside is that the resultant noise distribution is the Irwin-Hall distribution, not the Gaussian distribution. The Irwin-Hall distribution itself is not a privacy-preserving noise for (ε,δ)𝜀𝛿(\varepsilon,\delta)-differential privacy nor Rényi privacy. Moreover, specific FL applications such as stochastic Langevin dynamics (Welling and Teh, 2011; Vono et al., 2022) or randomized smoothing (Duchi et al., 2012; Scaman et al., 2018) specifically require a Gaussian distribution. This motivates the development of advanced aggregate AINQ mechanisms.

4.3 Aggregate Q𝑄Q Mechanism

Let P=IH​(n,0,σ2)𝑃IH𝑛0superscript𝜎2P=\mathrm{IH}(n,0,\sigma^{2}) be the Irwin-Hall distribution. We have seen in Section 4.2 that the Irwin-Hall mechanism produces a noise with distribution P𝑃P. The idea is now to decompose the desired noise distribution Q𝑄Q (e.g. Gaussian) into a mixture of shifted and scaled versions of P𝑃P in the form “a​P+b𝑎𝑃𝑏aP+b”, use the global common randomness T𝑇T to select the shifting and scaling factors according to the mixture probabilities, and perform the Irwin-Hall mechanism with the input and output shifted and scaled. In this section, we construct a homomorphic aggregate AINQ mechanism with a noise distribution Q𝑄Q, called the aggregate Q𝑄Q mechanism, using this strategy.

Definition 7.

(Mixture set) For probability distributions P,Q𝑃𝑄P,Q, denote by ΠA,B​(P,Q)subscriptΠ𝐴𝐵𝑃𝑄\Pi_{A,B}(P,Q) the set of joint probability distributions πA,Bsubscript𝜋𝐴𝐵\pi_{A,B} of the random variables A∈ℝ𝐴ℝA\in\mathbb{R} and B∈ℝ𝐵ℝB\in\mathbb{R} such that if (A,B)∼πA,Bsimilar-to𝐴𝐵subscript𝜋𝐴𝐵(A,B)\sim\pi_{A,B} is independent of Z∼Psimilar-to𝑍𝑃Z\sim P, then A​Z+B∼Qsimilar-to𝐴𝑍𝐵𝑄AZ+B\sim Q.

Definition 8.

(Aggregate Q𝑄Q mechanism) Let S1,…,Sn∼i​i​d𝒰​(−1/2,1/2)superscriptsimilar-to𝑖𝑖𝑑subscript𝑆1…subscript𝑆𝑛𝒰1212S_{1},\ldots,S_{n}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle iid}}{{\sim}}\mathcal{U}(-1/2,1/2) and T=(A,B)∼πA,B∈ΠA,B​(P,Q)𝑇𝐴𝐵similar-tosubscript𝜋𝐴𝐵subscriptΠ𝐴𝐵𝑃𝑄T=(A,B)\sim\pi_{A,B}\in\Pi_{A,B}(P,Q). The aggregate Q𝑄Q mechanism is defined by w:=2​σ​3​nassign𝑤2𝜎3𝑛w:=2\sigma\sqrt{3n} and

ℰ(x,s,a,b):=⌈x/(aw)+s⌋,\displaystyle\mathscr{E}(x,s,a,b):=\left\lceil x/(aw)+s\right\rfloor,
𝒟¯​((mi)i,(si)i,a,b):=a​wn​(∑i=1nmi−∑i=1nsi)+b.assign¯𝒟subscriptsubscript𝑚𝑖𝑖subscriptsubscript𝑠𝑖𝑖𝑎𝑏𝑎𝑤𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript𝑚𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript𝑠𝑖𝑏\displaystyle\overline{\mathscr{D}}((m_{i})_{i},(s_{i})_{i},a,b):=\frac{aw}{n}\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n}m_{i}-\sum_{i=1}^{n}s_{i}\right)+b.

Basically, we generate A,B𝐴𝐵A,B randomly, and then run the Irwin-Hall mechanism scaled by A𝐴A and shifted by B𝐵B. The resultant noise distribution is Q𝑄Q as precised in the next Proposition.

Proposition 3.

The aggregate mechanism of Def.8 satisfies the AINQ property with noise distribution Q𝑄Q, and is homomorphic.111Technically, 𝒟¯¯𝒟\overline{\mathscr{D}} is not in the form (6) due to the “+b𝑏+b” term, though it can be absorbed into sisubscript𝑠𝑖s_{i}. Let bi′=b/nsubscriptsuperscript𝑏′𝑖𝑏𝑛b^{\prime}_{i}=b/n, and treat (si,bi′)subscript𝑠𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝑏′𝑖(s_{i},b^{\prime}_{i}) as the common randomness between client i𝑖i and the server. 4.4 Aggregate Gaussian Mechanism

We now study the case where Q𝑄Q is the Gaussian distribution, and describe the construction of πA,Bsubscript𝜋𝐴𝐵\pi_{A,B} which decomposes Q𝑄Q into a mixture of Irwin-Hall distributions. We call this the aggregate Gaussian mechanism.

Step 1. First, we study how to decompose 𝒰​(−1/2,1/2)𝒰1212\mathcal{U}(-1/2,1/2) (instead of Q𝑄Q) into a mixture of shifted and scaled versions of the Irwin-Hall distribution P𝑃P with a pdf f𝑓f. Assume f𝑓f is appropriately scaled so its support is [−1/2,1/2]1212[-1/2,1/2]. For −1/2≤x≤1/212𝑥12-1/2\leq x\leq 1/2, decompose 𝒰​(−1/2,1/2)𝒰1212\mathcal{U}(-1/2,1/2) into the mixture (1/f​(0))​f​(x)+(1−1/f​(0))​φ​(x)1𝑓0𝑓𝑥11𝑓0𝜑𝑥(1/f(0))f(x)+(1-1/f(0))\varphi(x) where φ​(x)=(f​(0)−f​(x))/(f​(0)−1)𝜑𝑥𝑓0𝑓𝑥𝑓01\varphi(x)=(f(0)-f(x))/(f(0)-1) is a bimodal distribution with modes {−1/2;1/2}1212\{-1/2;1/2\}, and can be decomposed into uniform distributions using the strategy in Section 3.1. These uniform distributions can be recursively decomposed into a mixture of a shifted/scaled f𝑓f and other uniform distributions, and so on. See Figure 3, and Algorithm DecomposeUnif in Appendix A.2.

Step 2. To decompose the Gaussian distribution Q𝑄Q with a pdf g𝑔g, we first decompose g𝑔g into the mixture g​(x)=λ​f​(x)+(1−λ)​ψ​(x)𝑔𝑥𝜆𝑓𝑥1𝜆𝜓𝑥g(x)=\lambda f(x)+(1-\lambda)\psi(x) where λ𝜆\lambda is as large as possible such that ψ𝜓\psi is still unimodal. A practical choice is λ=infx>0d​g​(x)/d​f​(x)𝜆subscriptinfimum𝑥0d𝑔𝑥d𝑓𝑥\lambda=\inf_{x>0}\mathrm{d}g(x)/\mathrm{d}f(x) if n≥3𝑛3n\geq 3, and λ=0𝜆0\lambda=0 if n≤2𝑛2n\leq 2. We then decompose ψ𝜓\psi into a mixture of uniform distributions, using the strategy in Section 3.1, and decompose those uniform distributions using the aforementioned strategy. Refer to Figure 3, and Algorithm Decompose in Appendix A.4.

4.5 Theoretical Analysis

We now study the communication cost. Assuming the data xisubscript𝑥𝑖x_{i} is bounded by |xi|≤t/2subscript𝑥𝑖𝑡2|x_{i}|\leq t/2 for i=1,…,n𝑖1…𝑛i=1,\ldots,n, we have |ℰ​(xi,Si,A,B)|≤⌈t/(2​w​|A|)⌉ℰsubscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝑆𝑖𝐴𝐵𝑡2𝑤𝐴|\mathscr{E}(x_{i},S_{i},A,B)|\leq\left\lceil t/(2w|A|)\right\rceil. Therefore, Misubscript𝑀𝑖M_{i} can be encoded into ⌈log⁡(t/(w​|A|)+3)⌉𝑡𝑤𝐴3\lceil\log(t/(w|A|)+3)\rceil bits conditional on A𝐴A. The expected amount of communication per client is upper-bounded by 𝔼​(⌈log⁡(t/(w​|A|)+3)⌉)𝔼𝑡𝑤𝐴3\mathbb{E}(\lceil\log(t/(w|A|)+3)\rceil) which is approximately equal to 𝔼​[−log⁡|A|]+log⁡(t/(2​σ​3​n))𝔼delimited-[]𝐴𝑡2𝜎3𝑛\mathbb{E}[-\log|A|]+\log(t/(2\sigma\sqrt{3n})) bits. Hence, we can construct an aggregate AINQ mechanism with a small amount of communication if we have a small 𝔼​[−log⁡|A|]𝔼delimited-[]𝐴\mathbb{E}[-\log|A|]. To study this quantity, we introduce a notion called relative mixture entropy.

Definition 9 (Relative mixture entropy).

Given probability distributions P,Q𝑃𝑄P,Q over ℝℝ\mathbb{R}, the relative mixture entropy is hM​(Q∥P):=supΠA,B​(P,Q)𝔼ΠA,B​[log⁡|A|]assignsubscriptℎMconditional𝑄𝑃subscriptsupremumsubscriptΠ𝐴𝐵𝑃𝑄subscript𝔼subscriptΠ𝐴𝐵delimited-[]𝐴h_{\mathrm{M}}(Q\|P):=\sup_{\Pi_{A,B}(P,Q)}\mathbb{E}_{\Pi_{A,B}}[\log|A|] where the supremum is over ΠA,B​(P,Q)subscriptΠ𝐴𝐵𝑃𝑄\Pi_{A,B}(P,Q).222Take log⁡0=−∞0\log 0=-\infty, so 𝔼​[log⁡|A|]=−∞𝔼delimited-[]𝐴\mathbb{E}[\log|A|]=-\infty if ℙ​(A=0)>0ℙ𝐴00\mathbb{P}(A=0)>0.

Relative mixture entropy has several desirable properties similar to the differential entropy (see Appendix A.1). In particular, hM​(Q∥P)≤h​(Q)−h​(P)subscriptℎMconditional𝑄𝑃ℎ𝑄ℎ𝑃h_{\mathrm{M}}(Q\|P)\leq h(Q)-h(P) can be upper-bounded in terms of the difference of differential entropies. We have the following bound on the communication cost in terms of hM​(Q∥P)subscriptℎMconditional𝑄𝑃h_{\mathrm{M}}(Q\|P).

Theorem 1.

(Complexity) Let P=IH​(n,0,σ2)𝑃IH𝑛0superscript𝜎2P=\mathrm{IH}(n,0,\sigma^{2}) be an Irwin-Hall distribution. Assume |xi|≤t/2subscript𝑥𝑖𝑡2|x_{i}|\leq t/2 for i=1,…,n𝑖1…𝑛i=1,\ldots,n. There exists an aggregate AINQ mechanism for simulating a noise distribution Q𝑄Q, with an expected amount of communication per client upper-bounded by

−hM​(Q∥P)+log⁡t2​σ​3​n+6​σ​3​n​log⁡et⋅𝔼Z∼Q​[|Z|]𝔼Z∼P​[|Z|]+1.subscriptℎMconditional𝑄𝑃𝑡2𝜎3𝑛⋅6𝜎3𝑛𝑒𝑡subscript𝔼similar-to𝑍𝑄delimited-[]𝑍subscript𝔼similar-to𝑍𝑃delimited-[]𝑍1-h_{\mathrm{M}}(Q\|P)+\log\frac{t}{2\sigma\sqrt{3n}}+\frac{6\sigma\sqrt{3n}\log e}{t}\cdot\frac{\mathbb{E}_{Z\sim Q}[|Z|]}{\mathbb{E}_{Z\sim P}[|Z|]}+1.

To give an upper bound on the expected communication cost, it remains to give a lower bound on hM​(Q∥P)subscriptℎMconditional𝑄𝑃h_{\mathrm{M}}(Q\|P).

Theorem 2.

(Lower bound) For two distributions P,Q𝑃𝑄P,Q with pdfs f,g𝑓𝑔f,g, respectively, that are unimodal, differentiable and symmetric around 00 with L:=2​sup{x:f​(x)>0}<∞assign𝐿2supremumconditional-set𝑥𝑓𝑥0L:=2\sup\{x:f(x)>0\}<\infty and λ:=infx>0d​g​(x)/d​f​(x)assign𝜆subscriptinfimum𝑥0d𝑔𝑥d𝑓𝑥\lambda:=\inf_{x>0}\mathrm{d}g(x)/\mathrm{d}f(x), we have

hM​(Q∥P)≥−(1−λ)​(L​f​(0)+log⁡e​L​(g​(0)−λ​f​(0))2​(1−λ)).subscriptℎMconditional𝑄𝑃1𝜆𝐿𝑓0𝑒𝐿𝑔0𝜆𝑓021𝜆\displaystyle h_{\mathrm{M}}(Q\|P)\geq-(1\!-\!\lambda)\!\left(Lf(0)+\log\frac{eL(g(0)-\lambda f(0))}{2(1-\lambda)}\right)\!.

We can then combine Theorems 1, 2 to give a bound on the communication cost of the aggregate Gaussian mechanism. The proofs of the theorems are given in Appendix B.6 and B.7. The pseudocode is given in Algorithms Encode and Decode in Appendix A.5. Figure 4 compares the communication cost per client of the aggregate Gaussian mechanism, individual Gaussian mechanism (direct layered quantizer) and Irwin-Hall mechanism where the bounds are computed using Theorem 1 and Theorem 2. We can see that the aggregate Gaussian mechanism can have a smaller communication cost than the individual Gaussian mechanism for a large number of clients, though not as small as the Irwin-Hall mechanism. We also remark that aggregate Gaussian is homomorphic (unlike individual Gaussian), and has a noise distribution that is exactly Gaussian (unlike the Irwin-Hall mechanism).

5 COMPRESSION AND SUBSAMPLING FOR PRIVACY

5.1 Trusted server with subsampling strategy

Subsampling (Li et al., 2012; Balle et al., 2018) is a technique for enhancing privacy, where only a subset of clients or their data is selected for transmission. It can be leveraged to reduce communication cost while improving DP guarantees. Recently, (Chen et al., 2023) introduced coordinate-wise subsampling to derive DP schemes with optimal communication utility tradeoffs. We now describe how this scheme can be improved with an AINQ mechanism.

We are interested in the subsampled individual Gaussian mechanism (SIGM) with shifted layered quantizer. First consider the case in dimension d=1𝑑1d=1 with n𝑛n clients and sampling variables B1,…,Bn∼ℬ​(γ)similar-tosubscript𝐵1…subscript𝐵𝑛ℬ𝛾B_{1},\ldots,B_{n}\sim\mathcal{B}(\gamma) (γ∈[0,1]𝛾01\gamma\in[0,1]), where Bi=1subscript𝐵𝑖1B_{i}=1 if client i𝑖i is selected and Bi=0subscript𝐵𝑖0B_{i}=0 otherwise. Let n~=∑iBi~𝑛subscript𝑖subscript𝐵𝑖\tilde{n}=\sum_{i}B_{i} be the number of selected clients and let ℰ,𝒟ℰ𝒟\mathscr{E},\mathscr{D} be the encoding and decoding functions in Def.5 for the noise distribution 𝒩​(0,(σ​γ​n)2)𝒩0superscript𝜎𝛾𝑛2\mathcal{N}(0,(\sigma\gamma n)^{2}). The mechanism works as follows: (1) generate the global shared randomness B1,…,Bn∼ℬ​(γ)similar-tosubscript𝐵1…subscript𝐵𝑛ℬ𝛾B_{1},\ldots,B_{n}\sim\mathcal{B}(\gamma); (2) generate the shared randomness Sisubscript𝑆𝑖S_{i} if Bi=1subscript𝐵𝑖1B_{i}=1; (3) client i𝑖i sends Mi=ℰ​(xi​n~,Si)subscript𝑀𝑖ℰsubscript𝑥𝑖~𝑛subscript𝑆𝑖M_{i}=\mathscr{E}(x_{i}\sqrt{\tilde{n}},S_{i}) if Bi=1subscript𝐵𝑖1B_{i}=1, or Mi=0subscript𝑀𝑖0M_{i}=0 if Bi=0subscript𝐵𝑖0B_{i}=0; and (4) server outputs Y=(γ​n​n~)−1​∑i:Bi=1𝒟​(Mi,Si)𝑌superscript𝛾𝑛~𝑛1subscript:𝑖subscript𝐵𝑖1𝒟subscript𝑀𝑖subscript𝑆𝑖Y=(\gamma n\sqrt{\tilde{n}})^{-1}\sum_{i:\,B_{i}=1}\mathscr{D}(M_{i},S_{i}). It can be checked that Y−(γ​n)−1​∑i:Bi=1xi∼𝒩​(0,σ2)similar-to𝑌superscript𝛾𝑛1subscript:𝑖subscript𝐵𝑖1subscript𝑥𝑖𝒩0superscript𝜎2Y-(\gamma n)^{-1}\sum_{i:B_{i}=1}x_{i}\sim\mathcal{N}(0,\sigma^{2}). The proof, the generalization to d𝑑d dimensional data, and the algorithm are included in Appendix A.6. This mechanism achieves the same statistical behavior as CGSM (Chen et al., 2023), with the benefit that it directly ensures an exact Gaussian noise through quantization without the need to first incur a compression error independently of DP noise. Invoking (Chen et al., 2023, Theorem 4.1) and Prop. 2, we have the following result.

Proposition 4.

If x1,…,xn∈[−c,c]dsubscript𝑥1…subscript𝑥𝑛superscript𝑐𝑐𝑑x_{1},\ldots,x_{n}\in[-c,c]^{d}, then SIGM is (ε,δ)𝜀𝛿(\varepsilon,\delta)-DP with a noise level of order

σ2=Θ​(c2​ln⁡(1/δ)n2​γ2+c2​d​(ln⁡(d/δ)+ε)​ln⁡(d/δ)n2​ε2),superscript𝜎2Θsuperscript𝑐21𝛿superscript𝑛2superscript𝛾2superscript𝑐2𝑑𝑑𝛿𝜀𝑑𝛿superscript𝑛2superscript𝜀2\sigma^{2}=\Theta\bigg{(}\frac{c^{2}\ln(1/\delta)}{n^{2}\gamma^{2}}+\frac{c^{2}d(\ln(d/\delta)+\varepsilon)\ln(d/\delta)}{n^{2}\varepsilon^{2}}\bigg{)},

where the cost per client is 𝒪​(γ​d​log⁡(2+c/(σ​n​γ)))𝒪𝛾𝑑2𝑐𝜎𝑛𝛾\mathcal{O}\left(\gamma d\log(2+c/(\sigma\sqrt{n\gamma}))\right), and the error 𝔼⁡[∥Y−n−1​∑ixi∥22]𝔼subscriptsuperscriptdelimited-∥∥𝑌superscript𝑛1subscript𝑖subscript𝑥𝑖22\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}[\left\lVert Y-n^{-1}\sum_{i}x_{i}\right\rVert^{2}_{2}] is at most d​c2n​γ+d​σ2𝑑superscript𝑐2𝑛𝛾𝑑superscript𝜎2\frac{dc^{2}}{n\gamma}+d\sigma^{2}.

Remark 1.

(Flattening and geometry) To extend this result for data bounded in ℓ2subscriptℓ2\ell_{2} norm, one may rely on flattening techniques to convert the ℓ2subscriptℓ2\ell_{2} geometry into an ℓ∞subscriptℓ\ell_{\infty} geometry and obtain tighter utility analysis. Using Kashin’s representation as in Chen et al. (2023) or some Walsh-Hadamard/Fourier transform as in Kairouz et al. (2021a), the SIGM mechanism enjoys the optimal utility bound of order 𝒪​(d/(n2​ε2))𝒪𝑑superscript𝑛2superscript𝜀2\mathcal{O}(d/(n^{2}\varepsilon^{2})). Observe that these flattening schemes require 𝒪​(d2)𝒪superscript𝑑2\mathcal{O}(d^{2}) or 𝒪​(d​log⁡d)𝒪𝑑𝑑\mathcal{O}(d\log d) depending on the operation.

Numerical comparison. We empirically evaluate our distributed mean estimation scheme SIGM with the method CSGM in a similar framework as in Chen et al. (2023). The parameter configuration is: number of clients n∈{1000;2000}𝑛10002000n\in\{1000;2000\}, dimension d∈{100;500}𝑑100500d\in\{100;500\}, probability of information accidentally being leaked δ=10−5𝛿superscript105\delta=10^{-5}, privacy budget ε∈[0.5;4]𝜀0.54\varepsilon\in[0.5;4] and subsampling parameter γ∈{0.3;0.5;1.0}𝛾0.30.51.0\gamma\in\{0.3;0.5;1.0\}. Figure 5 displays the mean squared errors (MSE) obtained over 100100100 independent runs. The number of bits used by CSGM is kept equal to the number of bits used by SIGM. For the same ε𝜀\varepsilon, γ𝛾\gamma and the number of bits used, SIGM allows a smaller MSE compared to the CSGM.

5.2 Less-trusted with SecAgg

The Distributed Discrete Gaussian (DDG) mechanism (Kairouz et al., 2021a) can leverage SecAgg to achieve differential privacy guarantees against the server, which is a stronger setting than that of the less-trusted server. However, in practical implementation, it often requires a much higher number of bits per coordinate.

We adapt the experiments from Kairouz et al. (2021a) which show the utility of the DDG mechanism with different number of bits against the standard Gaussian mechanism. On the other hand, using Elias gamma coding, we calculate the number of bits needed for the aggregate Gaussian mechanism and the individual mechanism using shifted layered quantizer to match a Gaussian mechanism. The results333The MSE curves for the DDG experiments are obtained with the original code of Kairouz et al. (2021a). of Figure 6 are obtained over 303030 runs with n=500𝑛500n=500 and d=75𝑑75d=75 and highlight the great performance of aggregate Gaussian. While DDG offers stronger privacy guarantees, i.e., DP against the server, it comes at a heavy cost in terms of bits in comparison to aggregate Gaussian, which is also compatible with SecAgg.

Appendix:

Compression with Exact Error Distribution for Federated Learning

Appendix A is dedicated to additional results on aggregated mechanisms with a focus on the relative mixture entropy and the details of the algorithms used in Section 4. Appendix B gathers all the proofs of the theoretical results. Appendix C presents additional details and results for the numerical experiments. Appendix D presents how the proposed quantizers with exact error distribution can be applied to obtain optimal algorithms for non-smooth distributed optimization problems.

Appendix A Additional results on aggregated mechanisms

A.1 Properties of relative mixture entropy

Proposition 5.

The relative mixture entropy satisfies:

  1. 1.

    (Shifting and scaling) Let X,Y𝑋𝑌X,Y be random variables, and denote the distribution of X𝑋X as PXsubscript𝑃𝑋P_{X}. For constants a,c≠0𝑎𝑐0a,c\neq 0 and b,d∈ℝ𝑏𝑑ℝb,d\in\mathbb{R},

    hM​(Pc​Y+d∥Pa​X+b)=hM​(PY∥PX)+log⁡|c||a|.subscriptℎMconditionalsubscript𝑃𝑐𝑌𝑑subscript𝑃𝑎𝑋𝑏subscriptℎMconditionalsubscript𝑃𝑌subscript𝑃𝑋𝑐𝑎h_{\mathrm{M}}(P_{cY+d}\|P_{aX+b})=h_{\mathrm{M}}(P_{Y}\|P_{X})+\log\frac{|c|}{|a|}.
  2. 2.

    (Concavity in Q𝑄Q) For a fixed P𝑃P, hM​(Q∥P)subscriptℎMconditional𝑄𝑃h_{\mathrm{M}}(Q\|P) is concave in Q𝑄Q.

  3. 3.

    (Chain rule) For distributions P,Q,R𝑃𝑄𝑅P,Q,R,

    hM​(R∥P)≥hM​(R∥Q)+hM​(Q∥P).subscriptℎMconditional𝑅𝑃subscriptℎMconditional𝑅𝑄subscriptℎMconditional𝑄𝑃h_{\mathrm{M}}(R\|P)\geq h_{\mathrm{M}}(R\|Q)+h_{\mathrm{M}}(Q\|P).
  4. 4.

    (Bound via differential entropy) If P,Q𝑃𝑄P,Q are continuous distributions,

    hM​(Q∥P)≤h​(Q)−h​(P),subscriptℎMconditional𝑄𝑃ℎ𝑄ℎ𝑃h_{\mathrm{M}}(Q\|P)\leq h(Q)-h(P),

    where h​(P)ℎ𝑃h(P) is the differential entropy of P𝑃P.

Proof.

Property (1) is straightforward. To show concavity (2), consider λ∈[0,1]𝜆01\lambda\in[0,1] and two distributions Q1,Q2subscript𝑄1subscript𝑄2Q_{1},Q_{2}, and consider (A1,B1)subscript𝐴1subscript𝐵1(A_{1},B_{1}) independent of (A2,B2)subscript𝐴2subscript𝐵2(A_{2},B_{2}) independent of Z∼Psimilar-to𝑍𝑃Z\sim P such that A1​Z+B1∼Q1similar-tosubscript𝐴1𝑍subscript𝐵1subscript𝑄1A_{1}Z+B_{1}\sim Q_{1}, A2​Z+B2∼Q2similar-tosubscript𝐴2𝑍subscript𝐵2subscript𝑄2A_{2}Z+B_{2}\sim Q_{2}. A​Z+B∼λ​Q1+(1−λ)​Q2,𝔼​[log⁡|A|]=λ​𝔼​[log⁡|A1|]+(1−λ)​𝔼​[log⁡|A2|].formulae-sequencesimilar-to𝐴𝑍𝐵𝜆subscript𝑄11𝜆subscript𝑄2𝔼delimited-[]𝐴𝜆𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝐴11𝜆𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝐴2\displaystyle AZ+B\sim\lambda Q_{1}+(1-\lambda)Q_{2},\qquad\mathbb{E}[\log|A|]=\lambda\mathbb{E}[\log|A_{1}|]+(1-\lambda)\mathbb{E}[\log|A_{2}|].

Taking supremum gives us the desired result. To show the chain rule (3), consider (A1,B1)subscript𝐴1subscript𝐵1(A_{1},B_{1}) independent of (A2,B2)subscript𝐴2subscript𝐵2(A_{2},B_{2}) independent of Z∼Psimilar-to𝑍𝑃Z\sim P such that Y=A1​Z+B1∼Q𝑌subscript𝐴1𝑍subscript𝐵1similar-to𝑄Y=A_{1}Z+B_{1}\sim Q, and A2​Y+B2∼Rsimilar-tosubscript𝐴2𝑌subscript𝐵2𝑅A_{2}Y+B_{2}\sim R. h​(Q)=h​(A​Z+B)≥h​(A​Z+B|A,B)=h​(Z)+𝔼​[log⁡|A|].ℎ𝑄ℎ𝐴𝑍𝐵ℎ𝐴𝑍conditional𝐵𝐴𝐵ℎ𝑍𝔼delimited-[]𝐴\displaystyle h(Q)=h(AZ+B)\geq h(AZ+B\,|\,A,B)=h(Z)+\mathbb{E}[\log|A|].

∎

A.2 Algorithm DecomposeUnif

As an intermediate step, we study how we can simulate 𝒰​(−1/2,1/2)𝒰1212\mathcal{U}(-1/2,1/2) using a noise with p.d.f. function f𝑓f that is unimodal, symmetric around 00, and supported over [−1/2,1/2]1212[-1/2,1/2] (e.g. a scaled version of Irwin-Hall). The idea is to recursively express uniform distributions as mixtures of shifted and scaled versions of f𝑓f and other uniform distributions, and repeat ad infinitum.

We now describe the operation of decomposing 𝒰​(−1/2,1/2)𝒰1212\mathcal{U}(-1/2,1/2) into a mixture of shifted and scaled versions of f​(x)𝑓𝑥f(x). For the sake of simplicity, assume f​(x)𝑓𝑥f(x) is unimodal, symmetric around 00, and supported over [−1/2,1/2]1212[-1/2,1/2] (e.g. a scaled version of Irwin-Hall). First, we can express the uniform distribution 𝒰​(−1/2,1/2)𝒰1212\mathcal{U}(-1/2,1/2) as a mixture of f​(x)𝑓𝑥f(x) and other uniform distributions as follows. Generate U∼𝒰​(−1/2,1/2)similar-to𝑈𝒰1212U\sim\mathcal{U}(-1/2,1/2) independent of V∼𝒰​(0,1)similar-to𝑉𝒰01V\sim\mathcal{U}(0,1). If V≤f​(U)/f​(0)𝑉𝑓𝑈𝑓0V\leq f(U)/f(0), then generate X∼fsimilar-to𝑋𝑓X\sim f. If V>f​(U)/f​(0)𝑉𝑓𝑈𝑓0V>f(U)/f(0) and U>0𝑈0U>0, then take S=f−1​(V​f​(0))𝑆superscript𝑓1𝑉𝑓0S=f^{-1}(Vf(0)) (where f−1​(y):=inf{x≥0:f​(x)≤y}assignsuperscript𝑓1𝑦infimumconditional-set𝑥0𝑓𝑥𝑦f^{-1}(y):=\inf\{x\geq 0:\,f(x)\leq y\}), and generate X∼𝒰​(S,1/2)similar-to𝑋𝒰𝑆12X\sim\mathcal{U}(S,1/2). If V>f​(U)/f​(0)𝑉𝑓𝑈𝑓0V>f(U)/f(0) and U<0𝑈0U<0, then take S=f−1​(V​f​(0))𝑆superscript𝑓1𝑉𝑓0S=f^{-1}(Vf(0)), X∼𝒰​(−1/2,−S)similar-to𝑋𝒰12𝑆X\sim\mathcal{U}(-1/2,-S). Then we can show that X∼𝒰​(−1/2,1/2)similar-to𝑋𝒰1212X\sim\mathcal{U}(-1/2,1/2). We can then recursively express these uniform distributions in the mixture as mixtures of shifted and scaled versions of f​(x)𝑓𝑥f(x) and other uniform distributions, and repeat ad infinitum.

Algorithm DecomposeUnif takes f𝑓f and a random number generator 𝔓𝔓\mathfrak{P} as input (where we can invoke 𝔓​()𝔓\mathfrak{P}() to obtain a 𝒰​(0,1)𝒰01\mathcal{U}(0,1) random number), and outputs two random variables A,B𝐴𝐵A,B such that if we generate X∼fsimilar-to𝑋𝑓X\sim f, then A​X+B∼𝒰​(−1/2,1/2)similar-to𝐴𝑋𝐵𝒰1212AX+B\sim\mathcal{U}(-1/2,1/2).

A.4 Algorithm Decompose

The goal is to simulate an additive noise channel with a noise p.d.f. g𝑔g that is unimodal, symmetric around 00 and differentiable knowing that we can simulate an additive noise channel with a noise p.d.f. f𝑓f with same properties. The naive and quite inefficient way is to decompose g𝑔g into a mixture of uniform distributions, and run the DecomposeUnif algorithm on those uniform distributions. Instead, we first decompose g𝑔g into the mixture

g​(x)=λ​f​(x)+(1−λ)​ψ​(x)𝑔𝑥𝜆𝑓𝑥1𝜆𝜓𝑥g(x)=\lambda f(x)+(1-\lambda)\psi(x)

where λ𝜆\lambda is as large as possible such that ψ𝜓\psi is still unimodal. A practical choice is λ=infx>0d​g​(x)/d​f​(x)𝜆subscriptinfimum𝑥0d𝑔𝑥d𝑓𝑥\lambda=\inf_{x>0}\mathrm{d}g(x)/\mathrm{d}f(x) if n≥3𝑛3n\geq 3, and λ=0𝜆0\lambda=0 if n≤2𝑛2n\leq 2. We then decompose ψ𝜓\psi into a mixture of uniform distributions, and run DecomposeUnif. Algorithm Decompose below computes the decomposition of g𝑔g into a mixture of shifted and scaled versions of f𝑓f. It takes f,g𝑓𝑔f,g and a random number generator 𝔓𝔓\mathfrak{P} as input, and outputs two random variables A,B𝐴𝐵A,B such that if we generate X∼fsimilar-to𝑋𝑓X\sim f, then A​X+B∼gsimilar-to𝐴𝑋𝐵𝑔AX+B\sim g.

A.5 Algorithms for Aggregate Gaussian Mechanism

We describe the encoding and decoding algorithms for the aggregate Gaussian mechanism. We assume the server and all the clients share a common random seed, which they use to initialize their pseudorandom number generators (PRNG) 𝔓𝔓\mathfrak{P}. Since each PRNG is initialized with the same seed, they are guaranteed to produce the same common randomness (Si)i,A,Bsubscriptsubscript𝑆𝑖𝑖𝐴𝐵(S_{i})_{i},A,B at the clients and server.

B.3 Proof of Proposition 2

For the Gaussian case, refer to Wilson (2000, Page 22). We prove the case for Laplace random variable with a similar strategy. Note that fWsubscript𝑓𝑊f_{W} is translation invariant w.r.t to fZsubscript𝑓𝑍f_{Z}, so we consider zero mean Laplace. For Z∼Laplace​(0,b)similar-to𝑍Laplace0𝑏Z\sim\text{Laplace}\left(0,b\right), we have fW​(x)=−b​ln⁡(2​b​x)−b​ln⁡(1−2​b​x)subscript𝑓𝑊𝑥𝑏2𝑏𝑥𝑏12𝑏𝑥f_{W}(x)=-b\ln(2bx)-b\ln(1-2bx). Solving d​fW​(x⋆)/d​x=0dsubscript𝑓𝑊superscript𝑥⋆d𝑥0\mathrm{d}f_{W}(x^{\star})/\mathrm{d}x=0 gives x⋆=1/4​bsuperscript𝑥⋆14𝑏x^{\star}=1/4b so that fW​(x⋆)=2​b​ln⁡2subscript𝑓𝑊superscript𝑥⋆2𝑏2f_{W}\left(x^{\star}\right)=2b\ln 2 and plug the value b=σ/2𝑏𝜎2b=\sigma/\sqrt{2} to conclude.

We then demonstrate that the mechanism is homomorphic. Since 𝒟¯¯𝒟\overline{\mathscr{D}} only depends on m1,…,mnsubscript𝑚1…subscript𝑚𝑛m_{1},\ldots,m_{n} through ∑imisubscript𝑖subscript𝑚𝑖\sum_{i}m_{i}, it allows the server to decode using only ∑imisubscript𝑖subscript𝑚𝑖\sum_{i}m_{i} and the shared randomness. While 𝒟¯¯𝒟\overline{\mathscr{D}} is technically not in the form (6) due to the “+b𝑏+b” term, that term it can be absorbed into sisubscript𝑠𝑖s_{i}. Let bi′=b/nsubscriptsuperscript𝑏′𝑖𝑏𝑛b^{\prime}_{i}=b/n, and treat (si,bi′)subscript𝑠𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝑏′𝑖(s_{i},b^{\prime}_{i}) as the common randomness between client i𝑖i and the server. We then have 𝒟¯​((mi)i,(si,bi′)i,a)=a​wn​(∑i=1nmi−∑i=1n(si−bi′))¯𝒟subscriptsubscript𝑚𝑖𝑖subscriptsubscript𝑠𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝑏′𝑖𝑖𝑎𝑎𝑤𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript𝑚𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript𝑠𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝑏′𝑖\overline{\mathscr{D}}((m_{i})_{i},(s_{i},b^{\prime}_{i})_{i},a)=\frac{aw}{n}\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n}m_{i}-\sum_{i=1}^{n}(s_{i}-b^{\prime}_{i})\right), which is in the form (6) by taking 𝒟​(m,(s,b′),a)=a​w​(m−s+b′)𝒟𝑚𝑠superscript𝑏′𝑎𝑎𝑤𝑚𝑠superscript𝑏′\mathscr{D}(m,(s,b^{\prime}),a)=aw(m-s+b^{\prime}).

For the communication cost per client, Proposition 2 gives

Appendix C Additional Numerical Experiments

Comparing AINQ mechanism with Quantization. Applying the shifted layered quantizer with a required compression error 𝒩​(0,σ2​Id)𝒩0superscript𝜎2subscriptI𝑑{\cal N}(0,\sigma^{2}\mathrm{I}_{d}) coordinate-wise to an input x∈ℝd𝑥superscriptℝ𝑑x\in\mathbb{R}^{d} that is unbounded does not necessarily lead to a bounded encoding M𝑀M (alternatively bounded number of bits to send M𝑀M). However, a classical implementation of quantization starts by specifying the number of bits, then normalizing x𝑥x by ∥x∥psubscriptdelimited-∥∥𝑥𝑝\left\lVert x\right\rVert_{p} to scale it to the ℓpsubscriptℓ𝑝\ell_{p} unit sphere and finally perform quantization on each coordinate using b𝑏b bits. For decompression, ∥x∥psubscriptdelimited-∥∥𝑥𝑝\left\lVert x\right\rVert_{p} is shared with the decoder to rescale the quantized vector. The communication cost of sharing ∥x∥psubscriptdelimited-∥∥𝑥𝑝\left\lVert x\right\rVert_{p} may be ignored as it is often negligible after normalizing by the dimension d𝑑d. To have a fair comparison with classical quantization schemes, in DP experiments, shifted layered quantization is used to reproduce the desired error distribution. Then, the number of bits used by the shifted layered quantizer is measured on the one hand and the number of bits for quantization is adjusted on the other hand such that it is always equal or higher than the number of bits used for shifted layered quantizer.

For Langevin dynamics, the number of bits b𝑏b is specified first. Each client i∈[n]𝑖delimited-[]𝑛i\in[n] scales its vector xisubscript𝑥𝑖x_{i} by ∥xi∥∞subscriptdelimited-∥∥subscript𝑥𝑖\left\lVert x_{i}\right\rVert_{\infty}. The variance σb2subscriptsuperscript𝜎2𝑏\sigma^{2}_{b} used for the compression is calculated using Proposition 2 with t=2𝑡2t=2. Finally, decoding achieves a compression error of variance σb2​∥x∥∞2superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑏2superscriptsubscriptdelimited-∥∥𝑥2\sigma_{b}^{2}\left\lVert x\right\rVert_{\infty}^{2}. As σb2subscriptsuperscript𝜎2𝑏\sigma^{2}_{b} is known and the different norms {∥xi∥∞}i∈[n]subscriptsubscriptdelimited-∥∥subscript𝑥𝑖𝑖delimited-[]𝑛\left\{\left\lVert x_{i}\right\rVert_{\infty}\right\}_{i\in[n]} are shared, the server does some accounting to calculate the error variance of the distributed mean operation and adjusts the added error to reproduce the desired Markov chain. Refer to Algorithm 6 for more details.

Software/Hardware details. The code to reproduce the curves in the Figures below is available upon request. Other experiments were reproduced through the original implementation of Kairouz et al. (2021b) and Vono et al. (2022). The experiments on differential privacy applications (see Appendix C.1) were performed on a laptop Intel Core i7-10510U CPU 1.80GHz ×\times 8. The experiments on stochastic Langevin dynamics (see Appendix C.2) with toy gaussian data were performed on 4 cores of slurm-based cluster with 2.1 Ghz frequency. The computations for Langevin experiments required around 72 hours.

For a subsampling parameter γ∈{0.3;0.5;1.0}𝛾0.30.51.0\gamma\in\{0.3;0.5;1.0\}, we set δ=10−5𝛿superscript105\delta=10^{-5} and privacy budget ε∈[0.5;4]𝜀0.54\varepsilon\in[0.5;4]. The data is generated in a similar spirit to Chen et al. (2023). Denote by Xi​(j)subscript𝑋𝑖𝑗X_{i}(j) the j𝑗j-th coordinate of the i𝑖i-th client data. Then, for i∈[n]𝑖delimited-[]𝑛i\in[n] and for j∈[d]𝑗delimited-[]𝑑j\in[d], Xi​(j)∼(2​ℬ​(p)−1)​U/dsimilar-tosubscript𝑋𝑖𝑗2ℬ𝑝1𝑈𝑑X_{i}(j)\sim(2\mathcal{B}(p)-1)U/\sqrt{d} where ℬ​(p)ℬ𝑝\mathcal{B}(p) is a Bernoulli variable with parameter p=0.8𝑝0.8p=0.8 and U∼𝒰​(0,1)similar-to𝑈𝒰01U\sim\mathcal{U}(0,1) is a standard uniform variable. The multiplication by this uniform variable allows to work on continuous data X𝑋X whereas the experiments in (Chen et al., 2023) consider discrete values. Less-Trusted Server. The Distributed Discrete Gaussian (DDG) mechanism (Kairouz et al., 2021a) can leverage SecAgg to achieve DP guarantees against the server, which is a stronger setting than that of the less-trusted server. However, in practical implementation, it often requires a much higher number of bits per coordinate. The DDG mechanism relies on the discrete Gaussian distribution (Canonne et al., 2020) 𝒩ℤ​(μ,σ2)subscript𝒩ℤ𝜇superscript𝜎2\mathcal{N}_{\mathbb{Z}}(\mu,\sigma^{2}) with μ,σ∈ℝ𝜇𝜎ℝ\mu,\sigma\in\mathbb{R} and σ>0𝜎0\sigma>0. For any x∈ℤ𝑥ℤx\in\mathbb{Z}, ℙ𝒩ℤ​(X=x)subscriptℙsubscript𝒩ℤ𝑋𝑥\mathbb{P}_{\mathcal{N}_{\mathbb{Z}}}(X=x) is proportional to exp⁡(−(x−μ)2/(2​σ2))superscript𝑥𝜇22superscript𝜎2\exp(-(x-\mu)^{2}/(2\sigma^{2})). Using this discrete Gaussian noise, the DDG mechanism works as follows. The input parameters are: scaling factor γ𝛾\gamma; clipping threshold c>0𝑐0c>0; bias β≥0𝛽0\beta\geq 0; modulus m∈ℕ𝑚ℕm\in\mathbb{N} and noise scale σ2superscript𝜎2\sigma^{2}. The shared randomness is composed of a random unitary matrix U∈ℂd×d𝑈superscriptℂ𝑑𝑑U\in\mathbb{C}^{d\times d}. Each client i∈[n]𝑖delimited-[]𝑛i\in[n] first scales and clips the data as xi′=γ−1​min⁡{1,c/∥xi∥2}⋅xisuperscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖′⋅superscript𝛾11𝑐subscriptdelimited-∥∥superscript𝑥𝑖2superscript𝑥𝑖x_{i}^{{}^{\prime}}=\gamma^{-1}\min\left\{1,c/\left\lVert x^{i}\right\rVert_{2}\right\}\cdot x^{i} then rotate xi′′superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖′′x_{i}^{{}^{\prime\prime}} = U​xi′𝑈superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖′Ux_{i}^{{}^{\prime}} and quantize xi′′superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖′′x_{i}^{{}^{\prime\prime}} to Misubscript𝑀𝑖M_{i} such that ∥Mi∥2≤C​(γ,β,c)subscriptdelimited-∥∥subscript𝑀𝑖2𝐶𝛾𝛽𝑐\left\lVert M_{i}\right\rVert_{2}\leq C(\gamma,\beta,c). The worker finally sends to the server M~i=Mi+Gimodmsubscript~𝑀𝑖modulosubscript𝑀𝑖subscript𝐺𝑖𝑚\tilde{M}_{i}=M_{i}+G_{i}\mod m, where Gi∼𝒩ℤ​(0,σ2)similar-tosubscript𝐺𝑖subscript𝒩ℤ0superscript𝜎2G_{i}\sim\mathcal{N}_{\mathbb{Z}}(0,\sigma^{2}) using SecAgg. The server receives the results of SecAgg M~=∑inM~imodm~𝑀modulosuperscriptsubscript𝑖𝑛subscript~𝑀𝑖𝑚\tilde{M}=\sum_{i}^{n}\tilde{M}_{i}\mod m and outputs (γ/n)​U∗​M𝛾𝑛superscript𝑈𝑀(\gamma/n)U^{*}M (rescale and inverse the rotation). For more details, refer to Algorithms 1 and 2 in Kairouz et al. (2021a). Note that some recent work of Chen et al. (2022) aims at improving communication efficiency of DDG by applying projections to reduce the dimension of the data transmitted. However, it still uses DDG as a subroutine so we restrict our comparison to DDG.

To compare with the utility-communication trade-off of DDG, we adapt the experiments from Kairouz et al. (2021a). On the one hand, we reproduce the figures comparing the utility of DDG with different number of bits against the standard Gaussian mechanism. On the other hand, using Elias gamma coding, we measure over 505050 runs the average number of bits needed for the aggregate Gaussian mechanism and the shifted layered quantizer to match the Gaussian mechanism. Note that only the aggregate Gaussian mechanism is compatible with SecAgg. Figures 8 and 9 below presents the mean squared error curves for different number of clients n∈{100;500;1000}𝑛1005001000n\in\{100;500;1000\} and highlights that AINQ mechanisms requires much lower number of bits to realize the Gaussian mechanism. The graphs in Figure 9 compare the number of bits per client for the shifted layered quantizer (fixed or variable length) and the aggregate Gaussian mechanism, for a privacy budget ε∈[1,10]𝜀110\varepsilon\in[1,10].

C.2 Langevin Dynamics

C.2.1 Quantized Langevin Stochastic Dynamics

We consider the same FL framework as Vono et al. (2022) where the goal is to perform Bayesian inference on a parameter θ∈ℝd𝜃superscriptℝ𝑑\theta\in\mathbb{R}^{d} with respect to a dataset 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D}. The posterior distribution is assumed to admit a product-form density with respect to the d𝑑d-dimensional Lebesgue measure in the form

π​(θ|𝒟)=Cπ−1​∏i=1ne−Ui​(θ),Cπ=∫ℝd∏i=1ne−Ui​(θ)​d​θformulae-sequence𝜋conditional𝜃𝒟superscriptsubscript𝐶𝜋1superscriptsubscriptproduct𝑖1𝑛superscript𝑒subscript𝑈𝑖𝜃subscript𝐶𝜋subscriptsuperscriptℝ𝑑superscriptsubscriptproduct𝑖1𝑛superscript𝑒subscript𝑈𝑖𝜃d𝜃\displaystyle\vspace{-0.2cm}\pi(\theta|\mathcal{D})=C_{\pi}^{-1}\prod_{i=1}^{n}e^{-U_{i}(\theta)},\qquad C_{\pi}=\int_{\mathbb{R}^{d}}\prod_{i=1}^{n}e^{-U_{i}(\theta)}\mathrm{d}\theta\vspace{-0.2cm}

where Uisubscript𝑈𝑖U_{i} are clients’ potential functions. Using a sequence (Hk)k∈ℕsubscriptsubscript𝐻𝑘𝑘ℕ(H_{k})_{k\in\mathbb{N}} of unbiased estimates of ∇U=∑i=1nUi∇𝑈superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript𝑈𝑖\nabla U=\sum_{i=1}^{n}U_{i}, the Langevin dynamics with stochastic gradient aims at sampling from a target distribution with density π𝜋\pi. Starting from θ0∈ℝdsubscript𝜃0superscriptℝ𝑑\theta_{0}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}, it is a Markov chain defined by the update rule: θk+1=θk−γ​Hk+1​(θk)+2​γ​Zk+1subscript𝜃𝑘1subscript𝜃𝑘𝛾subscript𝐻𝑘1subscript𝜃𝑘2𝛾subscript𝑍𝑘1\theta_{k+1}=\theta_{k}-\gamma H_{k+1}(\theta_{k})+\sqrt{2\gamma}Z_{k+1} where γ>0𝛾0\gamma>0 is a discretization stepsize and (Zk)k∈ℕsubscriptsubscript𝑍𝑘𝑘ℕ(Z_{k})_{k\in\mathbb{N}} is a sequence of i.i.d. standard Gaussian random variables.

In the framework of Vono et al. (2022), at iteration k𝑘k, a subset 𝒜k+1⊂[n]subscript𝒜𝑘1delimited-[]𝑛\mathcal{A}_{k+1}\subset[n] of clients is selected. Each client i∈𝒜k+1𝑖subscript𝒜𝑘1i\in\mathcal{A}_{k+1} computes an estimate of Hk+1,isubscript𝐻𝑘1𝑖H_{k+1,i} and sends 𝒞​(Hk+1,i−H~k+1,i)𝒞subscript𝐻𝑘1𝑖subscript~𝐻𝑘1𝑖\mathscr{C}(H_{k+1,i}-\widetilde{H}_{k+1,i}) to the server where 𝒞𝒞\mathscr{C} is a compression operator and H~k+1,isubscript~𝐻𝑘1𝑖\widetilde{H}_{k+1,i} is a variance reduction term. The server aggregates the clients gradients estimators, potentially compensates for the variance reduction, and updates the process. Throughout the remaining of this subsection, we consider 𝒞𝒞\mathscr{C} to be a shifted layered quantizer with a fixed number of bits as described at the beginning of Appendix C and returning x+𝒩​(0,σb2​∥x∥∞2),σb2​∥x∥∞2←𝒞​(x)←𝑥𝒩0superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑏2superscriptsubscriptdelimited-∥∥𝑥2superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑏2superscriptsubscriptdelimited-∥∥𝑥2𝒞𝑥x+{\cal N}(0,\sigma_{b}^{2}\left\lVert x\right\rVert_{\infty}^{2}),\;\;\sigma_{b}^{2}\left\lVert x\right\rVert_{\infty}^{2}\leftarrow\mathscr{C}(x).

C.2.2 Experiments on Gaussian

We adapt this experiment from Vono et al. (2022). We use n=20𝑛20n=20 clients with data dimension d=50𝑑50d=50 and local potentials Ui​(θ)=∑j=1Ni‖θ−yi,j‖2/2subscript𝑈𝑖𝜃superscriptsubscript𝑗1subscript𝑁𝑖superscriptnorm𝜃subscript𝑦𝑖𝑗22U_{i}(\theta)=\sum_{j=1}^{N_{i}}\|\theta-y_{i,j}\|^{2}/2 where (yi,j)subscript𝑦𝑖𝑗(y_{i,j}) is a set of synthetic independent but not identically distributed observations across clients and Ni=50subscript𝑁𝑖50N_{i}=50. The data is generated by sampling yi,j∼𝒩​(μi,Id)similar-tosubscript𝑦𝑖𝑗𝒩subscript𝜇𝑖subscriptI𝑑y_{i,j}\sim{\cal N}(\mu_{i},\mathrm{I}_{d}) with μi∼𝒩​(0,25​Id)similar-tosubscript𝜇𝑖𝒩025subscriptI𝑑\mu_{i}\sim{\cal N}(0,25\mathrm{I}_{d}). We set the discretization stepsize γ=5×10−4𝛾5superscript104\gamma=5\times 10^{-4} and use full participation and full batch. We adapt the QLSD⋆ algorithm from Vono et al. (2022) to leverage the error of compression in the Langevin dynamics. If the error of compression is smaller than the required error, then the server adds additional noise. Otherwise, the server adds no additional noise to the dynamics. The theoretical analysis in Vono et al. (2022) still holds with this adaptation as it still satisfies the required assumptions on the compression operator (refer to their assumption H3).

Figure 10 above shows the behavior of the mean squared error (MSE) between the true parameter and the sampling based estimation. We start sampling after 4.5×1054.5superscript1054.5\times 10^{5} iteration to be sure the chain converge to a stationary distribution. The results were computed using 303030 independent runs of each algorithm. Observe the great performance of shifted layered quantizers schemes. Indeed, all schemes using standard unbiased quantization performs worse than all schemes with shifted layered quantizers.

Appendix D Compression for Randomized Smoothing in Federated Learning

In this section, we show how the proposed quantizers with exact error distribution can be applied to obtain optimal algorithms for non-smooth distributed optimization problems (Scaman et al., 2018). In particular, we highlight the link between compression and randomized smoothing (Duchi et al., 2012). In the framework of federated learning with bi-directional compression (Philippenko and Dieuleveut, 2021), it allows us to derive fast convergence rates for non-smooth objectives. To the best of found knowledge, such rates for federated learning with client compression on non-smooth objectives are novel.

Federated Learning with double compression. Consider some optimization problems of the form

minθ∈ℝd⁡{f​(θ)=1n​∑i=1nfi​(θ)}subscript𝜃superscriptℝ𝑑𝑓𝜃1𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript𝑓𝑖𝜃\min_{\theta\in\mathbb{R}^{d}}\left\{f(\theta)=\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}f_{i}(\theta)\right\}

where fisubscript𝑓𝑖f_{i} are local losses and f𝑓f is a convex and potentially non-smooth objective function. Distributed Randomized Smoothing. Fast rates for non-smooth optimization problems can be attained using the smoothing approach of Duchi et al. (2012); Scaman et al. (2018). For σ>0𝜎0\sigma>0, denote by fσsubscript𝑓𝜎f_{\sigma} the smoothed version of f𝑓f defined by

fσ​(θ)=𝔼ξ⁡[f​(θ+σ​ξ)],subscript𝑓𝜎𝜃subscript𝔼𝜉𝑓𝜃𝜎𝜉\displaystyle f_{\sigma}(\theta)=\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}_{\xi}[f(\theta+\sigma\xi)],

where ξ∼𝒩​(0,Id)similar-to𝜉𝒩0subscriptI𝑑\xi\sim\mathcal{N}(0,\mathrm{I}_{d}) is a standard Gaussian random variable. If f𝑓f is L𝐿L-Lipschitz then fσsubscript𝑓𝜎f_{\sigma} is (L/σ)𝐿𝜎(L/\sigma) smooth and it holds (see Lemma E.3 in Duchi et al. (2012))

∀θ∈ℝd,f​(θ)≤fσ​(θ)≤f​(θ)+σ​L​d.formulae-sequencefor-all𝜃superscriptℝ𝑑𝑓𝜃subscript𝑓𝜎𝜃𝑓𝜃𝜎𝐿𝑑\displaystyle\forall\theta\in\mathbb{R}^{d},\quad f(\theta)\leq f_{\sigma}(\theta)\leq f(\theta)+\sigma L\sqrt{d}.

Thus, accelerated optimization algorithms such as Distributed Randomized Smoothing (DRS) can be applied by using the smoothed version of f𝑓f. These algorithms rely on approximating the smoothed gradient ∇fσ=1n​∑i=1n∇fi,σ∇subscript𝑓𝜎1𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛∇subscript𝑓𝑖𝜎\nabla f_{\sigma}=\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}\nabla f_{i,\sigma} with sampled subgradients of the form gi​(θ+σ​ξj)subscript𝑔𝑖𝜃𝜎subscript𝜉𝑗g_{i}(\theta+\sigma\xi_{j}) with j=1,…,m𝑗1…𝑚j=1,\ldots,m. Each local client i=1,…,n𝑖1…𝑛i=1,\ldots,n can sample standard Gaussian variables then compute g^i​(θ)=1m​∑j=1mgi​(θ+σ​ξj)subscript^𝑔𝑖𝜃1𝑚superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑚subscript𝑔𝑖𝜃𝜎subscript𝜉𝑗\hat{g}_{i}(\theta)=\frac{1}{m}\sum_{j=1}^{m}g_{i}(\theta+\sigma\xi_{j}) and send it to the server which aggregates the subgradients. Interestingly, the sampling steps may be replaced with compressors that produce exact error distribution.

Quantizers act as randomized smoothing. The idea of sampling a random perturbation ξ𝜉\xi to evaluate the subgradients as gi​(θ+σ​ξ)subscript𝑔𝑖𝜃𝜎𝜉g_{i}(\theta+\sigma\xi) can be replaced by first compressing the model parameter θ𝜃\theta with a Gaussian error distribution as ℰ​(θ)=θ+σ​ξℰ𝜃𝜃𝜎𝜉{\mathscr{E}}(\theta)=\theta+\sigma\xi and then evaluating the subgradients at compressed point as gi​(ℰ​(θ))subscript𝑔𝑖ℰ𝜃g_{i}({\mathscr{E}}(\theta)). Similarly to Philippenko and Dieuleveut (2021), let us consider the update rules where the subgradients are evaluted at perturbed point as

θk+1=θk−γn​∑i=1ng^i​(θ^k);θ^k=ℰ​(θk)=θk+ξk,formulae-sequencesubscript𝜃𝑘1subscript𝜃𝑘𝛾𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript^𝑔𝑖subscript^𝜃𝑘subscript^𝜃𝑘ℰsubscript𝜃𝑘subscript𝜃𝑘subscript𝜉𝑘\displaystyle\theta_{k+1}=\theta_{k}-\frac{\gamma}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}\hat{g}_{i}(\hat{\theta}_{k});\quad\hat{\theta}_{k}={\mathscr{E}}(\theta_{k})=\theta_{k}+\xi_{k},

with a Gaussian error ξk=ℰ​(θk)−θk∼𝒩​(0,σ2​Id)subscript𝜉𝑘ℰsubscript𝜃𝑘subscript𝜃𝑘similar-to𝒩0superscript𝜎2subscriptI𝑑\xi_{k}={\mathscr{E}}(\theta_{k})-\theta_{k}\sim\mathcal{N}(0,\sigma^{2}\mathrm{I}_{d}). In view of approximating the sampling scheme of DRS, the local clients can perform m𝑚m local compressions so that g^i​(θ^k)=1m​∑j=1mgi​(θk+σ​ξj)subscript^𝑔𝑖subscript^𝜃𝑘1𝑚superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑚subscript𝑔𝑖subscript𝜃𝑘𝜎subscript𝜉𝑗\hat{g}_{i}(\hat{\theta}_{k})=\frac{1}{m}\sum_{j=1}^{m}g_{i}(\theta_{k}+\sigma\xi_{j}) which gives an unbiased estimate of the smoothed gradient as 𝔼⁡[g^i​(θ^k)|θk]=∇fi,σ𝔼conditionalsubscript^𝑔𝑖subscript^𝜃𝑘subscript𝜃𝑘∇subscript𝑓𝑖𝜎\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}[\hat{g}_{i}(\hat{\theta}_{k})|\theta_{k}]=\nabla f_{i,\sigma}. Thus, one can exactly recover the Distributed Randomized Smoothing algorithm of Scaman et al. (2018) and the optimal convergence rates of Theorem 1 therein.
